As Dirk van Dijk implies the most important measure for SS is not life expectancy at birth but life expectancy at age 65. In 1940 that was 12.8 years. As of 2010 that has increased to about 18.8 years. That’s an increase of 6 years. We’ve already increased the retirement age to 67 (by 2 years) for those born after 1960.

And Bob Paulson is only half right. In 1977 life expectancy at age 65 for those in the bottom half and the top half of the income distribution was 14.8 and 15.5 years respectively, or a difference of 0.7 years. By 2006 life expectancy at age 65 for those in the bottom half and the top half of the income distribution was 16.1 and 21.5 years respectively or a difference of 5.4 years. Life expectancy has improved tremendously in the last thirty years for senior citizens, provided you're in the right half of the income distribution.

As a highly educated african american who had two over-achieving professional parents that sent me to private school I feel that I have a few things in common with Mr. Hill.  Although I think he makes valid points I believe there's something missing--compassion and underdstanding.  As I came of age and began to learn more about the world I became aware that there were aspects of my background and personality that made me an "oreo" in some peoples' eyes.  I'm not sure that this is the same as "uncle tom" but I know that we used the former terminology much more in my peer group which is only a bit older than Mr. Hill's.  As I enter middle age and have endeavored to have substantive experiences with people from every walk of life and sought to understand everyone's point of view I can't escape the fact that my background is different than those who grew up in poor inner city neighborhoods.  There is a part of me that fits the characterizations in the documentary; I would have liked to see Mr. Hill make a similar insightful, honest admission.  I am glad that Mr. Rose has apparently grown since he was 18-years old.  If Mr. Hill cannot understand where he was coming from back then perhaps he still has some growing up to do.

Homo Sapiens are evolved with a brain designed to survive (as omnivores) and reproduce in the African Savannah not to act consistent with some a priori derived ethical precepts such as, "it is wrong to kill animals except in self defense." Morality is a luxury that only well fed persons can afford to indulge in. However unless one is utterly oblivious to the lot of the world's masses of humans, one will realize that most people can hardly afford to spend time grappling with such pressing philosophical questions as whether it is intellectually consistent to eat sausage in the morning while cuddling with one's dog at night when one lives on less than a dollar a day as about half the world's population does.

If one accepts that humans ought care more about whether an adult human lives or dies than an adult dog (which assuming no "handicap" even Peter Singer does), and one accepts the hardly debatable fact that human compassion and charity are limited resources, than its a virtual tautology that humans can spare no compassion for animals unless and until abject human poverty and degradation are eradicated. Given that that day is unfortunately a long way off, "animal rights" will remain the province of the oblivious well-off or the transparently misanthropic.

It is interesting to me that most people living in industrial societies have lost the connection between life and food.  In hunter-gatherer groups and small family farms, taking a life to sustain life is the basis of giving thanks and complete, reverent use of the animal.  In our "modern" societies, we purchase packaged "product" called "meat" in a plastic container that has no resemblance of an animal.  While companion animals are alive in our presence, food animals are seldom seen by their consumers.  If everyone who consumes meat had to be willing to do the killing, we might feel differently about the connection between the animal and the food.

It's also tough luck for the honeybees which most people don't even consider animals since they are insects.
Most commercial beekeepers and many hobby beekeepers do not treat their bees very well - applying chemical miticides to the hive, discouraging the natural process of swarming, killing queens every year or two to replace with another queen, taking most of the honey and feeding them sugar water through the winter, disturbing the hive often - in short - factory farming of bees for the human "benefit" of honey and pollination fees.
There are more holistic, natural ways of keeping bees - chemical free and in Warre and top bar hives, with the emphasis on bee health and survival through the winter first before honey production for people. Slowly more and more hobby beekeepers are using these healthier beekeeping methods. But it will be awhile before bees get their rights to be treated as well as pets. They are incredible and amazing beings, each hive a superorganism.

We need the bees much more than they need us. It is time to treat them with more respect and care.

I have not weeded through all 16pp of comments so I apologize if any of this is redundant (the reason I failed to continue "weeding through"), but I hope to make an original contribution. I just have a couple of things to say about recruiting and Duke basketball. (By way of background and in the interest of full disclosure, let me just say I was at Duke with Grant and as a member of the student media had the chance to interact with him, the coaches, and his teammates a little more than I might have otherwise. I wrote for the paper and worked with and succeeded Seth Davis, now of SI.com and CBS, as the host of "Cameron Corner" on Duke's student cable TV station. I also covered ACC recruiting for a couple of years out of college in addition to my "day job" as a newspaper reporter.) First off, if I am not mistaken, Grant hosted Chris Webber on Webber's official recruiting visit and Webber turned down Duke's scholarship offer to go to UM. So unless Rose is differentiating his situation from Webber's (which he may very well be) it's difficult to argue that Coach K had no interest in persuading members of the Fab Five to come to Durham. Secondly, I think when people talk about recruiting they need to consider the process as a bit more nuanced than Rose is suggesting. First, they should understand just how it operates as a national (and now international) system that is similar to any other kind of sales or business network. (Though sometimes we see the business aspect become too "fluid," i.e., when envelopes of cash and brokering of AAU and high school players occurs. Re-read _Raw Recruits_ or any sports media outlet over the past 10 years for that matter.) Even though Duke is a "national school," Coach K and his staff at different times are going to have different kinds of relationships in different parts of the country. But beyond this systemic argument, you have to look at the story of EACH recruitment. Otherwise, you cannot determine why Player A may have been offered a scholarship--or been strongly recruited--over Player B. Thirdly, I think it is important to acknowledge that Duke usually does recruit a "certain type of player"--one that can help them compete at the highest level of college basketball and, at the same time, have a reasonable chance of thriving as a member of the student body socially and academically. Given the small size of the school (about 6500 undergrads vs. Michigan's 42,000) and the overall academic environment and standards, Duke coaches in all sports (ask Steve Spurrier about this one) have to carefully navigate the admission waters and negotiate and advocate for student-athletes who might not find themselves in the pool of "solid" applicants academically (and this situation transcends race). Having said that, I think one thing that no one has mentioned in this discussion (unless it happened on pp 5-16) is that Duke DOES recruit and offer scholarships (and admit) basketball players who meet Jalen Rose's profile, for lack of a better term. I'm not sure Grant's use of Nolan Smith is the best exemplar for this, given his extraordinary circumstances. But, without naming names out of respect for those student-athletes' privacy, I would say that at least during my time at Duke there certainly were basketball players whose parents were not educated at Yale and Wellesley and who did come from (financially) poor, single-parent households and grew up in inner-cities where they developed their skills on playground blacktops, to paraphrase one such player, that were covered with broken glass bottles.
